Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Story:
I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the ceremony tonight. Everyone’s counting on you.” My heart thudded. This ceremony wasn’t just a family gathering—it was a tradition passed down for generations, and my father had made it clear how important it was for me to step up this year. But as I tucked my phone away, my work app pinged. An urgent delivery had come in: a high-value package, signature required, recipient must be present. No exceptions. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, “This is your responsibility. Don’t mess it up.” 

I glanced at the clock. The delivery window overlapped exactly with the ceremony. If I missed the delivery, I’d risk my job. If I missed the ceremony, I’d let my family down and break a tradition that meant everything to them. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations—my family’s pride and trust, my job’s demands and my own sense of duty. I stood frozen, keys in one hand, ceremonial script in the other, torn between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
